title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: vignette demonstrates use ASAP functions analyzing single WAV files zebra finch vocalizations. ASAP designed large-scale longitudinal studies, core analysis functions work directly individual audio files, making easy explore understand data. ’ll cover: Audio Visualization - View spectrograms Bout Detection - Find singing periods Syllable Segmentation - Detect individual syllables Spectral Entropy - Measure spectral structure Fundamental Frequency - Extract pitch contours Amplitude Envelope - Analyze temporal dynamics

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
code: library(ASAP)  # Get path to example WAV file included with the package wav_file <- system.file("extdata", "zf_example.wav", package = "ASAP")

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: visualize_song() function creates spectrogram visualizations audio recordings. typically first step exploring data.

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
code: # Visualize the entire recording visualize_song(wav_file) #> Song visualization completed for: zf_example.wav

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: can focus specific time range using start_time_in_second end_time_in_second:
code: # Visualize a 3-second segment visualize_song(wav_file,                 start_time_in_second = 1,                 end_time_in_second = 4) #> Song visualization completed for: zf_example.wav

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: “bout” continuous period singing. find_bout() function automatically detects bout boundaries using RMS (root mean square) amplitude thresholding bandpass filtering.
code: # Detect bouts in the recording bouts <- find_bout(wav_file,                     rms_threshold = 0.1,    # Amplitude threshold (0-1)                    min_duration = 0.7,      # Minimum bout length in seconds                    plot = TRUE)             # Show detection plot # View detected bouts as a table knitr::kable(bouts, digits = 3)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: rms_threshold: Higher values require louder sounds; lower values detect quieter vocalizations min_duration: Minimum bout length (filters short sounds/noise) freq_range: Bandpass filter range (default: 1-8 kHz zebra finch)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: segment() function detects individual syllables within specified time window using dynamic spectral thresholding.
code: # Segment syllables in a time window syllables <- segment(wav_file,                       start_time = 1,          # Start time (seconds)                      end_time = 5,            # End time (seconds)                      flim = c(1, 8),          # Frequency limits (kHz)                      silence_threshold = 0.01,                      min_syllable_ms = 20,    # Minimum syllable duration                      max_syllable_ms = 240,   # Maximum syllable duration                      min_level_db = 10,       # Starting threshold (dB)                      verbose = FALSE) # View detected syllables as a table knitr::kable(syllables, digits = 2)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: returned data frame contains: start_time/end_time: Syllable boundaries (seconds) duration: Syllable length silence_gap: Gap next syllable (useful syntax analysis) selec: Selection number tracking

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: Spectral entropy measures “randomness” structure frequency distribution. Harmonic sounds (like syllables) low entropy, noisy sounds high entropy.
code: # Calculate spectral entropy for a segment entropy_result <- spectral_entropy(wav_file,                                    start_time = 1.5,                                    end_time = 2.5,                                    method = "wiener",  # or "shannon"                                    normalize = TRUE,                                    plot = TRUE)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: Low entropy (near 0): Structured, harmonic sounds (e.g., tonal syllables) High entropy (near 1): Noisy, unstructured sounds (e.g., calls, noise)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: "wiener": Wiener entropy (ratio geometric arithmetic mean) "shannon": Shannon entropy (information-theoretic measure)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: FF() function extracts fundamental frequency (F0) contour, represents perceived pitch vocalization time.
code: # Extract fundamental frequency pitch_result <- FF(wav_file,                    start_time = 1.5,                    end_time = 2.5,                    method = "cepstrum",  # Cepstral analysis                    fmax = 1400,          # Maximum F0 to detect (Hz)                    threshold = 10,       # Confidence threshold                    plot = TRUE)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: fmax: Maximum fundamental frequency detect (1400 Hz typical zebra finch) threshold: Higher values filter uncertain estimates method: "cepstrum" (default) "yin" (requires Python librosa)

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: f0: Fundamental frequency values time time: Corresponding time stamps

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: amplitude envelope represents temporal dynamics sound intensity. Use amp_env() segmented data extract envelope profiles.  can also extract envelope individual syllables:
code: # Extract amplitude envelope for the second bout if (!is.null(bouts) && nrow(bouts) >= 2) {   env_bout <- amp_env(bouts[2, ],                        wav_dir = dirname(wav_file),                       msmooth = c(256, 50),                       norm = TRUE,                       plot = TRUE) } # Extract amplitude envelope for the 7th syllable if (!is.null(syllables) && nrow(syllables) >= 7) {   env_syl <- amp_env(syllables[7, ],                       wav_dir = dirname(wav_file),                      msmooth = c(256, 50),                      norm = TRUE,                      plot = TRUE) }

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: msmooth argument controls envelope smoothing: First value: Window length (samples) Second value: Overlap percentage

title: Single WAV File Analysis with ASAP
text: ’s typical workflow single-file analysis:
code: library(ASAP)  # 1. Load and visualize wav_file <- "path/to/your/recording.wav" visualize_song(wav_file, start_time_in_second = 0, end_time_in_second = 10)  # 2. Detect bouts bouts <- find_bout(wav_file, rms_threshold = 0.1, min_duration = 0.7)  # 3. Segment syllables if (!is.null(bouts) && nrow(bouts) > 0) {   syllables <- segment(wav_file,                        start_time = bouts$start_time[1],                        end_time = bouts$end_time[1],                        min_level_db = 10) }  # 4. Analyze acoustic features entropy <- spectral_entropy(wav_file,                              start_time = bouts$start_time[1],                             end_time = bouts$end_time[1])  pitch <- FF(wav_file,             start_time = bouts$start_time[1],             end_time = bouts$end_time[1])  # 5. Extract amplitude envelope env <- amp_env(bouts[1, ],                 wav_dir = dirname(wav_file),                msmooth = c(256, 50),                norm = TRUE,                plot = TRUE)

text: function performs clustering multiple stages: Temporal Clustering: Combines time position duration information Uses weighted features (controlled weight_time): weight_time > 1: Emphasizes temporal position duration weight_time = 1: Equal weighting weight_time < 1: Emphasizes duration temporal position UMAP-based Refinement: splits temporal clusters based UMAP coordinates Helps distinguish syllables similar timing different acoustic features Cluster Cleaning: Removes small clusters (controlled outlier_threshold) Merges similar clusters based UMAP proximity (controlled umap_threshold) Parameter Tuning Guidelines: eps_time: Controls temporal separation sensitivity Smaller values create temporal splits Typical range: 0.05-0.2 eps_umap: Controls acoustic feature sensitivity Smaller values create acoustic splits Typical range: 0.4-0.8 weight_time: Controls temporal vs duration importance Default (4) weights time 4x duration Increase temporal separation Decrease duration-based separation
